>>53094321
In the Christmas release thread, I called the dev lame for releasing on Christmas because I knew they would. But I was shitposting. They aren't lame, and neither is the hack. I knew it was coming around Christmas because I knew that they work on it very often, and it hadn't been released yet well into 2022, so after a while, a Christmas release date just made sense. Christmas, as a season, is very pretty and an aesthetic goldmine. It's a time to get comfy with the family, and people put up lights. Coral has frequently been called a pretty game, the GSC aesthetics are pretty comfy, as everyone always says, and the names of in-game cities have a Light motif. It suits Christmas well.

Anyway, the actual game is really good. Coral is probably the single best Generation 2 hack, whether it's finished or not. As someone else said, it really captures the essence of the Gen 2 era while offering up something new.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53105221
Horribly wrong is a complete overstatement. GSC aren't bad, they're just poorly implemented. They abandoned good beta Pokmeon designs. They made swarms, which are fun in theory, but made most of the swarm mons shitmons instead of rewarding to catch - and while the roaming mons are good, roaming is such a pill to deal with it's still not worth it either. They tried to copy RGBY's midgame open world, but instead of having multiple paths and a level curve set to an intended route like RGBY did they had a forked path and a level curve designed so that both paths were set to be your first. They got caught up on ideas like baby Pokemon that don't add anything to the core concept. They tried to have an extensive postgame in the form of Kanto but neglected to make it a challenge worthy of a postgame - and gimped the Elite 4 in the process.
But then, they also did the day/night cycle and had a day of the week cycle as well to create the illusion of a living world - and it works. They had a rival who was even more of a shithead than Green, which is saying something. They had weird things like shinies and Pokerus, even if they were a little too rare. They fixed up a few of the more lacking mons of the first generation. Hell, they had gym leaders who were actually remarkable for reasons besides "specializes in the most broken type in the game".
GSC and HGSS are overrated, but not horrifically so. People who try to argue that they are tend not to have played them.

Time for my threadly plug for the VN I'm writing. Hang out with Cynthia in Olivine City and solve crimes! Also featuring Jasmine. It's completely free.

writefuck.itch.io/olivinelights

>What's new?

Mostly finished writing a sidequest with Jasmine. It took a little while due to some writers' block, but it's in a good place. I've implemented some achievements (picrel) which primarily are there so the player/reader knows what content has and hasn't been seen yet. Achievements will be persistent between playthroughs and some of them also unlock things in an "extras" menu that will include things like showing your cynthia_love and jasmine_love stats, or starting off with your pokemon evolved. This will probably all be available in the next major update, but...

I'm having a hard time commissioning actual art for this for some reason. I need several SFW CG's and a whole bunch of NSFW ones, and I have plenty of money to throw at some artists, but out of everyone I PM'd or DM'd, almost no one has even answered me. Maybe I'm just being impatient, I dunno. I need a better way to recruit artists than just cold calling randos. I wish I had artist friends.

I'm getting increasingly uncomfortable with the fact that the VN contains art that's completely stolen from pixiv or deviantart and used without permission. My priority for commissioning CG's is to replace all the stolen art with paid art that I have permission to use. I might open up a ko-fi or something after I've done that. I won't put this behind a paywall, but I won't decline donations once I'm not using stolen art anymore. I'm not worried about official art or sprites stolen from Nintendo since I'm using their IP anyway, and I'm pretty sure I'm covered under fair use doctrine regardless. I just don't feel right stealing art from random strangers even though I'm not making money off of it. I might hold off on releasing another update until I have new art to replace the stolen assets. Not sure.

posts.com:
>>53107953
Try to not just follow a pre-established build for a pokemon. Use them as a guide at best. Figure out what your pokemon needs to do in the team, then figure out what are the threats it will face (usage stats help here), then which of these threats you can deal with, which ones you can't, and build your pokemon from there.
Figure out speed first, who you want to outspeed/underspeed. Then move to defenses, which hits you want to live (prioritize hp over def/spdef). Then move to attack, how many evs you need to OHKO or 2HKO something this pokemon is meant to check/face.
Weight each stat differently, if you're playing Breeloom, Meowscarada, or Flutter Mane you don't really need to prioritize defense over offense. Finally, figure out some common flows. I.e., if you see a Murkrow (prankster tailwind) or Indeedee/Armarouge (trick room) what's the best Turn 1 your team can do against it?
This is the best way to actually know what your team can do, instead of running into a situation and having no clue what move to use, or if you survive.

'It is recognized as a symbol of longevity. If its shell has algae on it, that Wartortle is very old.'

Going to assume PMD- a branching storyline and/or more player choice in general. I wanna go to the logical extreme of what Gates and BRT were going for. Just grab a buddy, go adventure somewhere, and eventually settle down someplace you like while improving your camp and eventually maybe even building a small town around it (possibly even a whole guild, but personally I’m sick to death of that concept. The choice would be cool for those who aren’t though). Granted, that’d probably fuck over the story (which is the only part of these games I truly love outside of the worldbuilding potential provided by the premise; everything else is just alright or good), so maybe it wouldn’t be worth the sacrifice…

posts.com: Professional author anon here, been thinking about starting a PMD story. What are some Do’s and Don’ts? What would you like and not like to see in a PMD fic?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53092254
There aren't really any set in stone tips. There are stories I've read that follow the usual story beats of "human wakes up a Pokemon, has amnesia, has to save the world with their new friends" and they're enjoyable. There are edgy as fuck stories that up the ante with heavier themes and violence, and with the right approach they can work. It's all dependent on the author and their style. Can you make a story and the world it occurs in believable? Can the characters be cared for by the audience? If you can achieve that, you're golden.

I will say though, my favorites are when people take the formula and run with just the basics. Talking Pokemon with their own society, teams that fulfill jobs and handle issues, some kind of overarching threat/plot, and enough to tie it all together nicely. Don't even have to involve humans or anything of the sort.

posts.com:
You’re walking in the woods with your rucksack. You aren’t the most experienced with packing your ruck, so it’s always so big on you. It’s 11 in the morning, beams of sunlight piercing the rooftop of the forest in small patches, here and there. After a bit of walking, you fight through foliage to see a girl sitting on a boulder. She’s wearing a black dress, has short black hair with a cowlick in the back, in her hair is a white bow. She notices you and greets herself. “I’m Marley. What brings you out here?” You can tell she’s kind of reserved and shy. You inform her that you’re just on a walk. “Really? You must know the way out of this forest. Can I join you?” You tell her “Yes” after a moment of contemplating. It seems kind of suspicious traveling with a girl who looks like she’s still in high school, but her companionship wouldn’t be too bad, especially since you often get lonely in your strolls. Time passes by, and she seems to have warmed up to you after some casual chitchat. “If I’m gonna be honest Anon, I don’t like talking. I can’t figure out what to say to people fast enough, so they just look at me with disgust and confusion. But I can talk to you normally, because you seem to understand me.” As you look at Marley, she looks away, blushing with a cute smile. She has feelings for you, but she’s far too nervous to let them known. After some walking, you both decide to sit under a tree to eat. You pull out goods from your rucksack, getting a can of beefaroni for yourself and giving a PBJ sandwich to Marley. After eating, you pack the trash away in your ruck. Marley is slightly appalled by your inability to effectively pack it tight. “Make it smaller Anon.” She lets out a small but cute chuckle as you begin to wrap around your ruck in a fetal position, humping it in a desperate yet pathetic attempt to make it smaller.
1/2

>>53104513
It's been suggested to me.

The issue for me is that I'm a stream of consciousness kind of writer. I don't "do" outlines and try to avoid knowing anything about what happens between the first and last line. (I try to find the ending before getting beyond a first or second chapter as applicable, but I don't want any idea of how I'll get there.) Taking a commission is the opposite. What will be "in" it will be prescribed and there are expectations of content. I want to write against expectations and with only the framing context having been predetermined.

I'd probably do much better on a patronage model than a contractor basis. Presuming I get back on the grind, someday.

Looking at the constant stream of journeyfics being posted on FFN got me thinking: is it rare for people to do a journeyfic in their homebrew region? It seems a lot more rare than I thought.

I've always had the idea for a journeyfic (as a Pokemon writer, who hasn't?), but I never really seemed to into the idea of using a canon region. Canon characters (gym leaders), yes. I this common with other Pokemon writers?

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53105573
I've gone somewhat the other way around.

Although the very first pokemon fic idea I had was in Johto by default, as I was playing HGSS at the time, once I decided to write it out and that some of my pokemon could talk (necessitating a conceit to sell it) I recast it as a homebrew region. It remains somewhat Johto like in broad strokes, and I pulled a bit of a stunt to keep them connected (that there is another archaeological site there claiming to also be the Ruins of Alph, implying a connection which I've left lying there for a decade…), but quickly became its own thing and gave me a lot of blank canvas to work with.

But now I've somewhat returned to it with my current WIP, which follows a canon-region trainer who is going to visit said Ruins, have an experience, and wind up on her way to my region.

As for why, I think that likely most writers want to self-insert and it's much easier to work in the Pokemon World by using places that are there. A homebrew region requires drawing a map to keep it straight.

>Canon characters (gym leaders), yes.
Those would be somewhat bound to canon regions, unless a bunch are visiting the homebrew land for… a convention I guess? See, it takes some doing.

We either go from one extreme (XY) to the other (the current series) when it comes to avoiding nostalgia pandering and going over the deep end with nostalgia pandering. Journeys could've struck a sweet spot had it not missed the easiest and most obvious opportunities to celebrate the anime's history while still covering new ground (Lt. Surge, the Pidgeot in the forest, use Ash's prior difficulties with some of his Pokemon like Charizard to guide Goh through his difficulties with some of his Pokemon, like Raboot), but JN's felt like it was allergic to its own potential as a series and steered clear of easy nostalgic nods.

>>53106320
Gen 1 is skippable
Gen 2 is arguably skippable, but if you want to play it, play Crystal.
Gen 3 is good, play FR or LG for the definitive Kanto experience, and play Emerald for Hoenn.
Gen 4 is mostly bad, carried by Platinum. HG or SS is the definitive Johto experience.
Gen 5 is pretty good, but be sure to play Black or White first, and then play their respective sequel next (B2 for Black, W2 for White)
Gen 6 is bad. Play X or Y, and then OR/AS if you skipped Emerald for the other Hoenn experience.
Gen 7 holds you hand. Don't bother with vanilla Sun/Moon, just play US/UM instead.
Gen 8 is carried by PLA so play that, only bother with Sw/Sh if you want you hand held even more.
Gen 9 exists.
Best games overall are Emerald, HG/SS, and Gen 5 as a whole.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53109251
Gen 6 is absolutely NOT "Gen 5 but anything". Gen 5 had a region that's completely linear for the first half and then opens up after you beat the league; Gen 6 has a region that loops around itself a couple times and only adds a couple new places to go after you beat the league.
Gen 5 only had Pokemon from its own generation before you beat the league, the largest roster of any generation. Gen 6 had the smallest roster of any generation and instead celebrated all of its predecessors.
Gen 5 had an enemy team that raised interesting moral questions that were completely tossed aside in the second half for a traditional good vs. evil affair. Gen 6 had an enemy team that raises no moral questions and introduces odd concepts in the back half like the immortal king.
You can say either one is better. I don't care what you like. But saying that Gen 6 is "Gen 5 but X" is nonsense. They're on the opposite ends of the Pokemon spectrum.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm having luck with a support Toxicroak in online raids. Really helps esp if the rest of the raid is solid offense.

Toxicroak
HP: 184, ATT: 252, SPE: 74
Nature: Adamant
Ability: Dry Skin
Tera: Doesn't matter. Mine is actually Fairy
@Mirror Herb but I've experimented with Shell Bell, Sludge and Snowball as well
>Taunt
>Mud Slap
>EQ
>Swords Dance

Taunt ASAP to stop Double Team spam, then Mud Slap until the cows come home while your team boosts up. Cheer if needed, SD up once you feel good about the accuracy drops, and EQ to victory. If Greninja resets its stats, go back to Mud Slap. You almost never need to attack if the raid team is offensive so you can just play support. With Mirror Herb you get the Evasion boost as soon as Greninja Double Teams, and the only thing it hits you with that actually hurts is Ice Beam but you are just bulky enough for even that to be a 3HKO. You're not going to be the damage dealer so don't expect to be. Just play support and you're golden. I've debated switching to defensive nature and EVs, may play around but this works well on solo raids for other Pokemon as well with some moveset tweaking (I replace Mud Slap and EQ with Drain Punch and Tera Blast Fairy) and a Shell Bell. I've yet to have issues but I also don't go into raids where I know I need to be the major damage dealer bc that's not this thing's job!

Yes, save after 60.
You usually eat the sandwich after you kill 60 unless you have troubles finding the mon, it depends on the outbreak.

Picnic reset is not always the best, there's a hard cap on how many pokemon can spawn around you, pokemon have specific spawns and if you sit still on the same spot you'll have to either wait until they move and more spawn or you'll get less spawns, personally I prefer moving around and respawning them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53107642
Outbreaks work on a per day basis and only on the outbreak itself.
So for example if you're doing a Flittle outbreak and you kill 60, it will boost the shiny odds for the flittle that spawn FROM the outbreak, not from the wild spawns.

Once the day rolls over, it will do new outbreaks, the game tries to give you an outbreak close to you and this is how you try to do specific outbreaks.

So your Flittle outbreak is gone and you'd have to do the battles again.
HOWEVER, you can just use the lets go auto battle thing, it can never kill a shiny and it will count on each kill, making it go by extremely fast

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53110072
>Ground
In Pokemon, Ground can be creatures that burrow (Diglett), have earth powers/control (Ursaluna, Groudon) or things relating to sand (Sandile, Hippowdon) or clay (Runerigus, though I'm with the majority who think it should've been Ghost/Rock).
>Rock
Rock are creatures composed of rock (Nacli), Roggenrola, have rock/mineral adornments (H Growlithe, Rockruff), fossils, crystals (Diancie).

All in all a relatively arbitrary distinction that admittedly can cross lines sometimes, with shit like Runerigus, Sandstorm, etc.

posts.name: Latias4Life
posts.com:
Good to be back!

First off, I made a Secret Garden themed phone notification sound for people to download and use if they want. I use it on Telegram! :D

Here: https://vocaroo.com/1i18eBQnqfhD

I also finally watched the two episodes of Pokemon: Aim to be a Pokemon Master with near perfect English translations, and I'm so convinced that it's movie 5 Latias!

- Ash recognizes her for SURE! He even asked her what was wrong point blank when all she was doing was seeming hostile toward him, like HE knew the behavior was strange for her.

- What are the odds that they'd decide to introduce an entirely different Latias? Makes little sense.

- I think it's just been too long since she last saw him, and she's been through too much. Also, she got hit pretty hard in the air and was possibly disoriented.

- You can tell Latias has the same affinity for him. I think there was a spark of realization when he got hit by the electricity while trying to rescue her from the icy globe. It was almost a "this is my knight in shining armor" way she saw him for a second.

- When she grabbed and flew with him and they held hands, you could tell she was kind of in shock, like she was experiencing old feelings.

- When she flew away at the end, she didn't revert to a "BAKA!" like tsundere personality. She just floated away with a really confused look in her eyes, like, "I need to process this."

Obviously there had to be some sort of conflict that they need to resolve between them. They can't just have Latias follow him around like a lovesick puppy.

Still kind of in shock that Latias beat Misty to having shippy moments. Ash really tended to Latias and seemed so loving... so heartwarming! I had a near perfect translation for episode 2 and Misty was obsessed with that clauncher, practically calling it her soulmate. Latias definitely has a better chance! Can't wait to see where this goes! :D

TPC was created for the singular purpose to sort out the rights-holding conflicts between Game Freak, Nintendo, and assorted individual contributors so that merchandizing agreements would only need to contact one address.

There's A LOT of the individual contributor stuff that fell through the cracks, like Shudo's Mewtwo and a bunch of gen 1 non-Suigimori art.

posts.name: Latias4Life
posts.com:
Gonna practice writing a couple small slices of life in case I want to finish my fic.

Pokemon Master ~ Day 27

Silvery moonlight cascaded down through the canopy of trees that sprawled in abundance throughout the Secret Garden. A June breeze caused branches and leaves to sway, creating scintillating moving patterns over a certain eon's minuscule and reflectively white feathers.

The humid, subtropical climate of Altomare was proving unusually cool this time of year with warm, moist air dominating, but occasional chilly gusts coming from a competing storm front to the north.

One such gust caused a certain human Pokemon master to shiver and whine in his sleep. Latias gazed at Ash with her golden eyes, taking in the details of his prone form, such as the way his skin scrunched up and formed little pimples, and how his dark, spiky coal black hair fluttered against his exposed forehead. He was fully covered the way humans seemed to prefer to be in public, but Latias wondered and fretted over if it was enough.

He looked so soft and vulnerable to the psychic and dragon type, his body far less powerful and resilient than her own. However, it was the strength of his heart and determination of his mind that caused Latias' heart to latch on to him, deciding to share with him any physical advantages she could.

"Laaaa," she whispered to her love as softly as she could before gently sliding a claw beneath his side and draping the other over him. In this embrace, she pulled him close to her soft, warm jetlike body, all exposed human skin becoming immersed in her down. The effort caused the large hammock they were sharing to swing back and forth, creating further friction against their spooning bodies.

When Ash's shivering stopped, the eon cooed and nestled her neck into the crook of his and closed her eyes. She still wasn't sure what their future held, but for now, having him near was enough. The sound of his heartbeat soon lulled her into a secure slumber.

There's also precedent that they've done it before in such a situation? Too much!

Maybe they just figured Latias' voice in the 5th movie was a bit too jarring and wanted to dial it back and the original VA couldn't accomplish it, and of course they couldn't use the old sounds cuz they wanted something new.

I remember too someone suggesting this Latias, if new, seems younger. Maybe she's actually just older. More mature . Doesn't need to vocalize or dart around like a juvenile like she used to. Maybe they wanted a new voice to reflect that. A lot can change when you've had to grow up quickly and you lose people you love. I still think she's processing her feelings and realizing she likes him again... or there's always the amnesia theory and she's falling in love all over again, wondering why it feels so familiar.

Gods, I don't know. I'm not giving up on team original Latias just yet. I feel like if she does confront him again, there's a 90% chance they'll acknowledge their past somehow. I can't see them bringing Latias back now that she's seemingly interested in him and leaving it completely ambivalent. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53103298
You can usually add parenthesis around a term in your prompt to emphasize it, and brackets to decrease the importance of a term. So the previous “cute, grey cat” might look like “[cute],((grey cat)). Also, copy the exact tags as used on danbooru such as: may (pokemon). just look it up in the internet, there's plenty of good tutorials out there atm

>Does it happen?
It'd happen.
Take a child on the verge of puberty, give it a small creature which will grow into a larger, more humanoid form, and send them on a journey where they will have to build a bond based on mutual cooperation and trust.
Where they will spend lengthy periods in the wilderness together, with only each other for company, as they both grow and mature in new and strange ways.
Everybody would subtly admit that there were trainers banging their Pokémon, some of these being supported by personal experience. This wouldn't be the case all of the time, I must stress, as you'd have just as many cases wherein the trainer-pokemon relationship is more sibling-like, or a friendship, but there would undoubtedly be cases where love (or at the least lust) bloomed.
>Legality
Maybe it would be considered fine. A time of sexual exploration for the budding, just another part of the coming of age ceremony which the trainer journey is.
After the trainer journey, things would likely change.
Pursuing relationships with Pokémon thereafter would be considered far more derisively, implying that one did not have the social skills or to attract another human, and had to resort to a Pokemon in turn, regardless of whether this was the case or not.
The degree to how much scorn/ridicule depends on a. How similar to a human the Pokemon is, and b. Whether the Pokemon is clearly also ok with your relationship. (Maybe also whether it could communicate easily, and whether the two of you could reproduce.)
If you had a Gardevoir or Machoke which was clearly affectionate towards you, you might face little more resistance than a few tasteless jokes.
If you had a Pokemon far smaller than you, which showed clear signs of abuse, well, someone might do something about it.
However, it wouldn't be illegal, merely frowned upon.
At least in some cases, as I will elaborate on later.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53110251
I could see trainers of notably dangerous pokemon (Pseudo-leg, Mega-Evos, etc) becoming romantically involved with their partners, for a practical reason.
A violent beast is less likely to kill the one it loves (or at least, the one it gets sexual pleasure from).
>Consent
Consent is difficult. For something to consent, we should assume it has an intelligence equivalent to an adult human.
To do that we must first determine a Pokemon's intelligence.
Intelligence varies throughout the series; with even members of the same species differing across depictions.
One of the games ways of implying intelligence in a species is to say it can understand human speech (See; Lapras, Lucario, Ninetales).
This is dissonant; undercutting the entire premise of the series, which is about giving orders to Pokémon, which would imply every Pokémon can understand human language, and thus, invalidate the previous claim.
We then can assume that every Pokemon is, at the least, as intelligent as a dog, being capable of understanding at least enough words to be able to understand its masters commands in a fight. Either that or they have unusually large language processing parts of the brain, but I digress.
When considering intelligent Pokemon, the first examples that come to mind are those whose minds exceed a humans: Alakazam, Slowking, Oranguru and Metagross are what immediately come to mind.
Dragonite is stated to have human level intelligence.
Ninetales, Lapras and Lucario are all noted for being "Highly intelligent" as previously noted. We will assume human intelligence, as discussed later.
Several others display traits which imply intelligence, but I will discuss them later when best relevant.
Reply with any notably smart Pokemon you can think of. I may have missed some.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53110380
The easiest way of determining whether a Pokemon can consent is whether it can speak.
Granted, this is not perfect, as a toddler can speak, and it is damn well not capable of consenting, but the immediate way of discerning whether a Pokemon can consent is being able to communicate with it.
The most notable talking Pokemon is clear; Meowth. He cannot be counted, however, in the sense that his having speech was clearly just for comedic effect, and not canon. The events which led to him learning human speech are never again seen throughout the entire franchise, despite numerous times where a Pokémon would have reason or ability to do so.
Canon examples of Pokemon capable of direct communication include:
>A lot of legendaries(Not that this would mean much to the average Joe)
>Lucario(Through aura telepathy)
>Zoroark and Ninetales(Through illusions)
>Ralts, and by extension gardevoir (Through telepathy)
>Lapras(You guessed it, telepathy)
And probably a few others I missed.
Psychic types could potentially be capable of telepathy as a whole, though they've never displayed this capability too much.
Once again, the ability to talk alone does not imply human-level intelligence, but is a decent litmus test, through which the Harkness test can be applied. One might even go so far as to claim that human level intelligence is not required, so long as both parties are clearly and blatantly consenting, but that is a debate I will not have.
Of course, the spoken word is not the sole form of communication. Language appears several times throughout the franchise. Of course, none would have the natural capacity to any more than you or I did as children, . Which actually can is difficult to discern, thanks to a lack of literary Pokemon in the franchise.
However, Weavile, (Again, a Pokemon which the games note for being smarter than usual) is stated to have created a vague language without any outside influence, using 500 characters scratched into trees.

Hosting guide (can we get this added to the FAQ?)

1. open map in pokemon
2. press home button
3. go to settings, scroll all the way down
4. go to time, about 1/3 down
5. make sure synchronize is off, scroll down again to open date and time
6. click A (7) times
7. press home
8. open pokemon and find the poison glowing raid
9. post code

this was a bitch to remake
all the fonts are different
the font rendering is different
the anti-aliasing, when it matters, is different
the browsers are different
the CSS is different
I ended up setting up a windows 2000 VM, set it up for the correct font rendering, installed a fucking period accurate HTML editor, and partially recreated the page.

so yeah there you go

>>53076892
We really need to define what exactly is iceberg material to begin with before doing this OP. As far as I know, iceberg infographics are used to show people dark and dubious secrets of the internet that not many people knows. The deeper the iceberg goes, the harder it is to find such information unless people dive deeper into the internet infrastructure. Many secrets can't be found on the surface (Google/search engines) while some can only be found in dubious imageboards or hobby websites (4chan/discord). The darkest secrets can only be uncovered by using TOR or P2P networks. This is how an iceberg should work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Peak of the iceberg
Very well known facts. Things that you can find and read from Google search without clicking on the link.
>Platform of the iceberg
Well known facts. Things you can find and read from websites listed on google search.
>Water level surface
Known facts. Things and pages that are being promoted on wiki homepages.

^^Anything above this level must come from TPCi themselves.^^

>Below water level
Less known facts. Things that you can find after clicking several layers of links from initial page that you originally clicked from google or wiki.
>Stem of the iceberg
Lesser known facts. Things that are being spoken regularly on imageboards, blogs, reddit, discord, etc.

vvMost (if not all) of stuffs below this level are +18 stuffs.vv

>Twilight zone
Not well known facts. Things that seldom being shared on degenerate imageboards such as /vp/. If you ask a typical pokemon fan, they may or may not know about them.
>Bottom of the iceberg
Mostly rumours. Things that rarely being talked about. Things that lack verifiable sources. You will never read about these things on wiki pages and their topics are highly regulated by admins.
>Below the iceberg
Mysterious rumours. No one knows how they started or where did they come from. Once in a while, someone will mention them on imageboards like 4chan. But there is absolutely no way to find and verify their sources.

>>53101880
Pao is absolutely broken, more than Chi-Yu ever was.
It outspeeds EVERYTHING except Dragapult which is weak to both its priority STABs for starters.
Tera Band Crunch 2HKOs at worst everything in the tier including resists, so absolutely nothing but certain scarfers, priority users or strategic Terastal mons can check it.
Tera Blast Electric beats all of its "checks" if you run HDB.
It's not that squishy either, 80/80 physical bulk is respectable.
Its defensive type is not that useless, it has key resistances that can be exploited.
Pao is a premier wallbreaker, revenge killer and sweeper all rolled into one. No other offensive mon in the tier can compress all offensive roles in a single set and excel at all of them at once.
Chi-Yu is a nuke, but 100 base speed means it either wallbreaks or runs scarf and Overheat can't be spammed as much as Pao's STABs, plus it has no priority.

posts.com:
Bored out of my mind and it wandred to comp, so I'm gonn type out some changes I'd make to the past 3 generational gimmicks if they're ever to return in an official capacity
>Megas
The stats gained now scale with the initial BST of the mon. For example, if a mon had less than, say, 500 BST, they'd get the full 100 BST boost, but if they had 600 BST, they'd get a heavily reduced BST bump of only around 10. This forces the already "strong" Pokemon getting Megas to take those optimal stats from an actual place they'd miss then rather than becoming nonsensical statblobs. If Mega Metgross still want its' 145 attack, 105 special attack, and 110 speed, it'll have to eat into it's HP, Defense, and Special Defense to do so even with the points afforded to it, whereas Megas like Audino and Sableye won't have to suffer. This also further pushes the "Megas as an alternative rather than straight updgrade" angle Kalosfags desperately want you to believe applied for more than a small handful of them.
>Z-Moves
When a Pokemon holding a Z-Crystal swaps in, the type of cystal it's holding is announced. For example, you swap Heatran holding a Grassium-Z in and the text "Heatran is a giving off an intensely verdant aura!" shows with an accompanying visual.
>Dynamax
Max HP bonus goes from 2x to 1.5x, ALL stat boosting Max Moves are capped to 100 BP in the BEST case, and Gmaxes are now given the option to use their Gmax moves alongside normal Max Moves. After they Gmax, another prompt like the initial DMax one shows up with a new symbol. Selecting it will allow you to hen use the Gmax move for the corresponding type of move that turn However, you can only do this ONCE. This change is gonna require a mass rebalancing of G-Max moves overall (the Kanto trio's moves literally only need to be used once to get max value in their current state, so cut their duration down to 4 turns, for example), but I think it'd be overall healthier.
Thoughts?

posts.com:
I was sitting and thinking about what kind of dragon you could bring to a trick room team since most dragons are just so fast and it kind of struck me.
How would a min-speed Haxorus work? Lets you put a bunch of stats into it's bulk/defenses instead of speed, will always underspeed Hydreigon because of it's natural 1 lower speed than Hydreigon and if you then also slap Brave on it with 0IV speed leaves you at 91 speed - which sure, is still fast for trick room but if you're facing a non-trick room team, you're most likely going to underspeed all of them. I guess you could also just bring a min-speed, Brave Dragonite since that technically underspeeds as well but it's so common. I like the idea of using Haxorus because Life Orb 252+ Haxorus using First Impression on Hydreigon is always a guaranteed kill unless they're very, very bulky or they tera. Which they might not do if they know stats and realize there is no scenario where Haxorus outspeeds a Hydreigon unless it's choice scarf. Haxorus's natural absolutely monstroud attack would also work well with stuff like a Bronzong so that it can levitate and you have ground coverage without only the use of Earth Power on like, Torkoal.

I dunno, I just wanna use weird shit on cart while I still can before fucking Paradoxes take over and the little bit of fun I had left in ladder is sucked out by the horde of Roaring Moon/Flutter Mane/Donphans come to shit on the parade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53109636
Ah, I see. Well, truth be told, Grapploct is easily the weakest link of the team, so I'd trade it out for a Dark or Normal type just to have a Ghost answer. Frankly, I see little reason not to throw in something like a Bisharp, which not only acts as a wincon in its own right, but can tank hits from Gengar and threaten it and Chandelure. It's also immune to Prankster from Grimmsnarly so SD can basically win you the game
Cloyster, Tang, and Empoleon are decent picks given what you're working with, and I think something like an Agility Petaya/Shuca Berry set for Empoleon could go really good in the lategame.

I'm thinking of something like this, although I will note I didn't build this with Tera in mind.

https://pokepast.es/e76ac3cc80b0c8ec

Idea behind the team is that you get up Rocks with Druddigon, chip everything with Talon/Drudd/Tang, and muscle through with one of the three sweepers. Ideally, you go Bisharp>Cloyster/Empoleon. AV is on Tang to tank at least one hit from Gengar and Knock it, Helmet on Drudd is to punish the shit out of Wak, and Wisp is kinda free into this team.

NP Golduck can still win but it's much harder

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53104595
>otherwise a skin flap that can peel down
The executive producer for Love Lost once drew a sketch page on that topic (don't ask, I got tired of carrying random image clutter years ago) but I've tried to avoid giving pokemon mammary glands. Miltank has a pass because the whole concept is that Pokemon tend to mimic the outward characteristics of animals and things but internally function quite differently. So a pokemon that mimics a dairy cow, which is selectively bred for lactation, sensibly mimics that capacity, but there's no real grounds for any other pokemon (that I know of) to offer dairy production.

>Whenever I see off model Gardevoir I always think of that
To be fair, I go off-model somewhat in my descriptions' details, because I prioritize motif and practicality over trying to bend over backwards to support the compromise that is cartoon art based off of what the sprite artists could pack into a Game Boy decades ago. Plus, there are greater narrative opportunities when you can have multiple levels of contrast. Allowing species with paws but anthropomorphic form (e.g., typhlosion or lucario) to be treated as not really having hands but being dexterous enough to get along in world built for fully functional thumbs opens the door for greater emphasis on pokemon who aren't given that conceit and must find other ways to struggle through, e.g. Idis, who has gotten a magnet embedded in her paw to be able to pick up things like pins and needles, which are very handy for picking locks and other things a naughty umbreon might want to do while not being suspected of being able to do them.

>remove the "blouse" and "gloves"
We can blame canon for this, for giving us a non-trivial number of pokemon with clothes-like…bodily components?…not really addressing them except for tongue-in-cheek hand-waves; like their reminding us that the spandex-and-belt appearance of machamp is not clothing and just what they look like, which only raises more questions.

>>53108413
I like Pokémon worldbuilding which accounts for the Pokémon as active participants in the world, not just tools for people.
For instance, one of the Pokemon settings I thought up has the franchises characteristic lack of explicit violence or dark themes being chalked up to a sort of Bene Gesserit order of gardevoirs/other select pokemon types, who have mentally/psychically manipulated mankind over the generations to be less unpleasant as a whole (All in the name of benefitting their trainers, of course). They've also used this to gain a position of power arguably equal to their supposed masters.
You see a ton of wars back in the lore of the games/anime, but nothing nearly so unpleasant in the current setting. Thought it'd be neat to explain that.

posts.com:
It's possible that all of the different creation myths for each region do not actually reflect the truth of the matter, or only represent partial truths. Perhaps at the time of gen 1, all know Pokémon at the time did share DNA with Mew, but newer Pokémon from newer regions disprove this.

PLA seems to suggest that there is some creator god, at least for the Sinnoh region if not the whole world, and Arceus seems to be its preferred avatar or some aspect of it's physical form, if not its true form.

Perhaps Mew was one of its first creations, or a descendant of it. Perhaps Pokémon like Dialga and Palkia Arceus supposedly created are just rumoured to be so.

I doubt we will ever get 100% confirmation on all these things because 1. I doubt GF have entirely thought it through themselves. 2. A mystery is always more interesting and leads to more fan debates without pissing off any specific segment of it and 3. Major corporations and media franchises do not like making definitive statements on theologtical matters, even for those in the Pokémon universe. Might scare away religious customers.

>be eh 7 or 8

>I fall straight down into stomach and knees
>Out of breath and gameboy is totally kill
>regain breath, notice fallen gameboy and run off crying
>go to PE area where no one is and just breakdown in grass
>find a gold necklace with a locket in grass
>open locket and see fancy pic of a girl I know and some man
>wipe tears away and go to find her
>find her in cafeteria
>give her necklace and she kisses me on the cheek and thanks me at least 10 times
>turns her back on me as she shows her friends she found it and I go back to empty PE area
>lay down on grass and see a cloud shaped like a big pretty bird
>makes me smile
>hear running sounds and “hey anon!” From hallway
>it’s cool rich friend and his sister
>gives me my crystal version cart
>mentions how he has 2 gameboy advances for trading and I can have one
>in disbelief so I hug him tight
>sister hugs both of us
>look back at bird cloud
>go back to cafeteria to get Hawaiian Punch and goldfish and we catch the beasts and ho-oh together
I will NEVER forget you Dallas. We were both pure of heart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Legends battle system was perfect. The camera movement and character animations was smooth and to the point, it didn't hang for a few seconds like in SV. The menus felt snappy and responsive unlike SV, and I loved how menu options were assigned to buttons. It's a crime that they went back to the fucking GameBoy menu in SV. The move animations were actually pretty good, and for the first time in the mainline games the Pokémon actually move around and make physical contact. I loved how time sometimes slowed down on the impact when you made super-effective hits and the camera shook a bit, it made battles feel a bit more action-packed. The battles in SV are fucking boring and look like shit. I also hate how zoomed in the battle camera is in SV.

There's also other stuff that Legends did that makes it so great, but I'm not gonna go into any of that. I'll just end it saying PLA was miles better than SV and anyone saying otherwise is a shill or a mindless NPC who doesn't want Pokémon to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043330
Hey, that's cool. I was just curious since the threads here always seems collector focus.

Radiant Pokemon are Pokemon that you can only have one of in your deck, but they're have powerful effects or attacks. So it's fun to try and choose which Radiant you want to use or work into your deck. Pic rel is one of the most popular ones, discard pile setup and drawing is really good for a lot of decks.

Radiant Eternatus is the main new one from CZ people like. When you bench it, you can search your deck for any two VMAX Pokemon and bench them as well. Which opens up a lot of opportunities for faster VMAX play.

>I was surprised people can just join games without even having the mod
The game is just a sandbox, when you sub to a workshop you're just getting a .json file telling the game to load different images, models, etc
Anybody that joins will just load the same information, the game will actually download these assets to make loading faster but if you don't want to clog your disk space turn Mod Cache off in the options.

>perhaps there should be a Steam group or something for Pokemon matchmaking
There probably is, lots of TTS discords popped up after the death of Global Chat, a shame. You could also host a lobby and post the info here so other anons can join. I don't play much these days but doing drafted/booster deck matches could be fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53072163
>Lance
I had a plan for this involving Agility Passing for the Mamoswine sweep, unfortunately that was no longer an option.
So before the battle, I give Miltank Thunderbolt, and Mamoswine Ice Beam.
Miltank leads, and it turns out, Gyarados struggles with SubMilk too, eventually falling to weather phenomena caused by a cow. Something about Greek mythology goes here.
Unfortunately, this is where it all goes downhill. I need to get Mamoswine in safely, but Miltank can't tank the strongest of the Dragonites indefinitely. Eventually I'm forced to switch in hopes of Outrage hitting in confusion, going to Sudowoodo instead, as probably the most expendable of the team.
He's able to Rock Slide the Dragonite, leading to the second one to come in. I'm not sure which one it is, so I stay in. Turns out it went for Thunder, which would've been a safe switch for Mamoswine. RIP Sudowoodo, your sacrifice won't be forgotten.
Mamoswine puts the DNite to ice, leading to Charizard.
I chose to believe Ancient Power would KO. I was wrong. Should've switched to Magcargo. Two hits was still enough, but Mamoswine is at critical health.
And Lance elects to throw out Dragonite instead of Aerodactyl.
So Lance is down to just Aerodactyl now. I switch to Magcargo here, not wanting to lose Mamoswine, and then go for Yawn. Magcargo lives at critical health, and it's clear that a sack is needed. In the end, while it's certainly the wrong choice in terms of future success, it's time for the milk factory to close down. RIP Miltank, what an absolute unit.
After this, Mamoswine comes in to clean house with Ice Beam + Ice Shard.

>>53102898
Crystal is done! Here's the breakdown of the final battle:
>Baku puts Pikachu to sleep. Red wastes a Full Restore to wake him up (while at full HP no less) before a Psychic takes him out in one hit.
>Espeon is next, Dagda makes easy work of him with a Mean Look + Toxic combo, along with Feint Attacks powered up with STAB + Black Glasses to speed up the process.
>For Snorlax, I had Dagda set up Mean Look + Toxic again before switching to Apis. A fully-powered Return with a held Pink Bow helps make this as painless as possible for me.
>Venusaur's turn; Kaso criticals a Flamethrower before he can do anything of note.
>Mazu is sent out against Blastoise, a Rain Dance-boosted Thunder is an OHKO.
>CHARIZARD is a chump thanks to Inanna's Surf (and a Mystic Water).
On to Emerald!

>>53089024
The probpem isn't being just too easy or hard. It's the game itself being inconsistent. For the first ~4 gyms, it works out pretty evenly, maybe easy if you don't have a full team, but then after Morty the levels drop out from under you, and depending on what you did early the result in gyms 5-7 is different:
> 1. Only had one/a few pokemon:
your team is probably at a higher level, you don't gain levels very much anymore, but you're already strong enough to quickly sweep through
> 2. already had 6:
Your team is even more likely to stop gaining experience ,but you also are about at the npc levels, so it's just low power STAB spam thanks to the weaker movepools unevolved/lower level mons generally have
>3. had a few, adding to the team:
the worst of both worlds, you have a few pokemon that are strong and can sweep, but any new additions will be weak and won't gain levels, so you're stuck with whatever it has when you catch it

Depending on which situation you're in, either you get to Clair and the league at their level and continue without much issue (this would be option 1), or your team is now relatively underleveled and still mot at their full potential, so it's more boring battles or grinding against the routes to get those last evos/moves (this is usually options 2 and 3)

And then no matter which one you were this time, you get to Kanto, the gyms are weaker, and it's just a casual walk around the region to destroy everything before being 10-20 levels under Red.

Other regions avoid this inconsistency thanks to the exp all, which does make them easy, but also much more well rounded to allow different playstyles instead of having drasitcally different experiences depending on when you caught your party.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53081614
Level curve is simply a way to add some difficulty to the game. Fighting red's team with level 40/level 50 mons is a completely different experience to fighting him with level 80 mons, and maxing out red's levels in other to raise the overall level curve means that less thoughtful players can't simply beat him by overlevelling him. The other reason behind the level curve is to make certain special mons like dragonite and tyranitar harder to get, as you need to actually commit to training their pre evolutions before obtaining them - and that only makes them feel that much special.

The other big misconception about gen 1 and gen 2 is that they are all about pokemon battling and thus they are bad because they are not filled with competitive pokemon with optimized move sets, because they and monster COLLECTING games where the real challenge is meeting and capturing as many pokemon as possible, not PvP battling. Gen 2 was the last gen where legendaries were actually elusive rather than handed to you by the plot, even suicune in crystal can be entirely missed if you don't want to follow him - and despite adding the battle tower as a true test for competitive pvp movesets, the real final challenge in that game isn't battling red, it's capturing the three legendary beasts just so you have a chance at battling and capturing ho oh.

People don’t see it this way these days but back then, spending ~hour each day leveling your mons in a nearby area, while engaging in side activities like the game corner, berry collecting, trainer rematches, bug catching contests etc in the downtime to break up the monotony, all that stuff, that WAS the content. That WAS the gameplay. Maybe one day you’d get lucky and run into a rare encounter on your way through an area, maybe you’d get a call about a swarm, maybe you finally win the bug catching contest, etc etc, each day brings with it potential for new experiences, it’s not always about clearing all of what technically counts as “content” in a given area ASAP and then moving on, you MAKE the content by creating your own story using the tools the game gives you. For me that means catching and training like 10-15 mons as I progress, and fully embracing the slower, routine based playstyle that asks of me. For others? Maybe they don’t really want to - and that’s ok. Those players can use proportionally less Pokémon, thus allowing them to progress through the game in a suitably swifter manor.
BUT
When people constantly whine about aspects of the game that aid my playstyle, getting in the way of theirs? Yea, I’m sorry, but it just sounds like you’re playing the game wrong, or more specifically, it sounds like you’re going into the game expecting it to give you an experience it’s not designed to, and then get mad when it doesn’t. You’re not “objectively wrong” or some shit, those issues you’re complaining about “exist”, sure, I wont be disingenuous with you there, but whether or not they’re “issues” at all is a matter of perspective, it may hinder your experience but it bolsters mine

GSC isn't supposed to be super hard

>game opens up
>you can choose which gyms to fight
>you can choose to beat team rocket first
>lots of areas to explore and pokemon to find
It makes grinding up to your opponents' levels for the hard battles a bit tedious, but you REALLY don't need to do that.
You should be able to win against the gyms and elite four with a solid 5-10 level disadvantage compared to the last ace pokemon, if you know what you're doing.
I won't argue that the game design is perfect. It makes some trainers really boring to fight and some really a lot harder, but I think its enjoyable as an overall experience

Based GSC enjoyer. The games really aren’t that difficult, but as with every pokemon game, the player has a lot of control over the difficulty of the experience. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53103619
>and why do you feel this way
Because the leveling system in Pokemon isn't as simple as just the numbers. When almost all of your team's progression is tied to levels, that 5-10 level gap means way more at 30 than it does at 60, and either you're destroying the NPCs with something that has reached its full potential against random NFEs, or using underpowered mons in long repetitive battles because you don't have any other options, especially in older games when most movepools are 90% weak non-STAB moves and the most useless status options.
A level 50 pokemon fighting a level 60 is a pretty even battle, a level 20 fighting a level 30 is usually very one-sided. The latter hapoens more often in Johto than basically any other region, and it makes the second half of the game feel like you're making barely any progress no matter how many battles you win
>the game doesn't tell you how many to train
They teach you how to catch pokemon, give you a bunch of pokeballs, tell you where to get more pokeballs, and then show you the PC where you can swap around your pokemon to decide which 6 will be in your team. The clear implication is that you will be catching pokemon all throughout your journey, and could use different ones at different times. This is also supported by the early-gen idea of pokemon like bug types being useful early and then replaced once stronger options are available.
Even if you only ever catch 6 pokemon, the odds of them all being in the first few routes is low, and only falls if you play the game multiple times, which makes the difference even more noticable if you catch something and it's 10 levels weaker than the rest of your team, on par with the routes, but nealry useless in the gyms.

I can see the argument about level disparities mattering more at lower levels making sense, especially where evolutions are involved.

>either you're destroying the NPCs with something that has reached its full potential against random NFEs, or using underpowered mons in long repetitive battles
The name of the game is exp management. I (almost) never find myself in either of these scenarios because I don’t allow myself to over level even when my team hasn’t been completed (less than 6). I will actively avoid trainer battles once my team has caught up to them (assuming my team is incomplete), so I can revisit them for easier leveling with new recruits. As for times where my team is underleveled, we’ve established that it doesn’t really matter, and that goes double for the level ranges where it occurs most noticeably (Clair, E4, and Red). You, the player, have active and dynamic control over your experience.

>most movepools are 90% weak non-STAB moves and the most useless status options.
You realize this applies to enemy trainers too, right? Those “useless” status moves are really effective at compensating for level disparities, as well. The AI can’t into swapping.

>could use different ones at different times
Key word being “could”. The implication is that you could do this, not that it will necessarily be useful to do so.

>This is also supported by the early-gen idea of pokemon like bug types being useful early and then replaced once stronger options are available.
AKA The trap every kid falls into in their first run. I’ve always viewed that as a hard lesson on being choosy with party members and boxing early evos ASAP. A few exceptions exist (Butterfree), but in keeping with the theme of GSC, there are plenty of stereotypical early route mon (Ledian, Ariados, Furret). Knowingly using this type of mon is an open invitation to a future grind.

>and that would be venom, not poison

No, that would be poison. Venom needs to be injected into the blood stream to cause any damage. Poison can be effective topically, inhaled, ingested, or injected. You can drink snake venom and be fine (generally), but doing the same with poison would kill you. Seeing as togepi just releases this into the air, it would be poison. This is why poison arrow frogs are called such, they secrete poisons and if you touch them you will die.

Hey Nishida simps, anti-Nishidafriend here. Just saw this Japanese-exclusive Nidoking promo for the first time. Honestly looks good. posts.name: Anonymous

>>53091992
Part of what I like about Komiya is the "painterly" quality of his work. I'm not sure if he's still using paints and pastels and shit, but his work still feels analog, and if it is all done in illustration software, it still gives a decent impression of brush strokes and physical mark making. A lot of these newer Komiya ripoffs (and I don't actually mean that, I like most of these artists you've brought up) feel very digital. Not that that's bad or anything -- I think honesty of materials is usually good. But I still like the feeling Komiya's work gives off.

Apart from that, I think Komiya is "overrated" or at least more highly regarded than a number of other illustrators with similar styles because he's been with the TCG since almost the beginning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53096563
Definitely helps to start with a specific goal in mind and broaden it as you fill out your collection. Focus, especially early on, will keep you from getting overwhelmed. If you collect things you’re genuinely interested in, instead of things that seem like good “investments” or something, the knowledge (and yeah, the value) will come naturally. Don’t buy cards in shitty condition just to fill out your collection — if you’re anything like me, you’ll just end up buying a mintier copy later on anyway. Just save the money and put it toward a copy you’d want to show off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53096726
Awesome. Solid goal, exactly how I started. I filled up a binder with base-fossil + black star promos and southern islands.

I meant to complete all the Neo sets, but then the Neo boom transitioned into the pandemic boom, and now it’s a huge pain in the ass to find raw cards in decent shape.

And just go for whatever condition works for you. When I first started, I just bought up everything I found that I didn’t already own, and I ended up getting heavily scratched or creased or dirty cards that I didn’t really want. I was just cautioning against that kind of attitude. The hobby generally rewards patience.

Oh and as far as patience goes, auctions are a solid way to get cheap cards. Put in a lot of lowball bids on cards you want. You won’t always win, but you can pretty often get cards for well under the average recent sale price.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53102443
Depends on how you feel about modern. If you like it, it's totally worth collecting. As far as collectors sets goes, it really just depends on what you like. But Crown Zenith isn't a bad start. Each pack has the potential to pull from a Galarian Gallery subset, which is absolutely loaded with gorgeous art. As the end of the SwSh era, it's pretty hyped up. Celebrations is also a good choice if you can still find it for retail. It celebrated the 25th anniversary and contains a subset with reprints of classic cards. The entire set itself is relatively small and the cards themselves aren't particularly expensive as singles, so it's very easy to complete. Shining Fates is another "special" set with some neat cards, but not really worth opening yourself since basically every card but Charizard can just be bought for a lower price than the products themselves.

Otherwise, all the recent sets have been pretty good. Evolving Skies is well known as a hype set because of its large list of chase cards. Brilliant Stars, Astral Radiance, Lost Origin, and Silver Tempest all have a trainer gallery subset which makes them all pretty fun.

Must be some sort of defense/feeding aid or something.
Imagine her situation: she is small, so she can't last too long in the wild, so she created that big mouth to defend herself. Now, her habitat are caves, wo if she can't feed on berries and roots, she has to eat minerals to survive, giving her the Steel type.
The big mouth was created from necessity, and a way to defend herself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53058241
Yeah, the way it's teeth are placed, along the outside rather than the inside, reminds me of crocodiles, meaning it likely doesn't use them to chew, at least not the things that can actually fit inside of them, unlike steel beams. And since the 'neck' that connects the jaws to Mawile's head is so small, it probably can't swallow anything either. If it did, it'd need to have an esophagus going down through the brain, which just sounds like a disaster waiting to happen.
Which means that Mawile's hind jaws probably act like a venus fly-trap, using secretions to dissolve whatever it holds inside and absorb the nutrients released down through the 'neck'. It would arrive at the brain first, so it'd also be a good biological explanation for why Mawile is smart enough to deceive others.

Gen 7 pokedex is the only one where Mawile is actually implied to eat things with the big mouth (Moon entry mentions it has no sense of taste, while Sun entry outright mentions Mawile swallows its prey whole using it). It's still mentioned to use them to chomp at things, but presumably that's just to subdue its prey and the actual eating is done with the real mouth.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53106835
I don't think people understand just how much something like this animation difference matters from a design perspective.
When playing Scarlet, your movement will always have a more distracting center of attention with the up and down motion. The same issue is magnified in Wyrdeer not dashing in PLA. Meanwhile, Miraidon's simpler movement animation is less distracting in a gameplay perspective, giving the player less visual distraction while running around.
I've played through both Scarlet and Violet over the winter with nothing to do and if I'm interested in shiny hunting, every time I will pick up Violet over Scarlet, unless it's for an exclusive. It's just easier to focus on what's happening around me when my bike isn't constantly jumping up and down.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53107882
The other anon summed it up but I'll still give it a go since I'm the anon you're responding to. Y is the Red game of Gen 6, and it's Pearl not Platinum that's the red game of Gen 4, along with the fact that you're forgetting Gold and Sun (and their remakes/other versions). The reason I said there were already 2 Pokemon Reds is because nobody counts Ruby or Shield as a "Pokemon Red"; sure they have red boxart, but their actual name theme comes before their coloring. Every pair of games has a Red and a Blue, it's a series staple, but of the games where the name theme is color, 3 of them are red and 1 of them is purple, which i suspect is why Violet is the vastly preferred version. Pokemon games named after colors are a classic trend that comprise almost half the series, it makes sense that a repeat color would sell less than a brand new color. Ruby or Pearl had the advantage of being gemstones, but Scarlet is the just the third shade of red to have been a title, paired against Violet, the 25+ year long awaited Pokemon Purple. It's a no-brainer.

Great, Lure, Premier, and Luxury all also work for varying reasons.

It's all fair points, but there's a difference - are we comparing what could have happened or what did happen?
Because we could describe SV like this too:
>Local professor starts bringing dangerous creatures and letting them loose until one of those killed him/her. Now the system is running amok with the impending risk of those monsters invading all of Paldea and destroying the local wildlife.

In other villainous plots there's a lot of intention and potential destruction yes, but nothing came off it. Ecoterrorists had half of the region under intense rain/sun for a couple of hours, local autist is chilling in another universe, French philantropist got himself killed and left a hole in a touristic zone, and impatient businessman left a crack at the top of a building and was sent into social work alongside his secretary.

In that regard probably Ghetsis takes the cake -we can see in B2W2 how tons of people ended losing their Pokémon, including your rival, or decided to abandon them because a guru told them so. Two years later the region is still healing and you can notice it.

SV is not just "the robot" -which wasn't even the bad guy-, it has a whole creepy hole about 700m deep, full of moths, bright powder and decades long abandoned scientific settlements. It has a scientist going crazy who didn't just get killed like Lysandr, also got killed while secluded in that creepy hole and without anyone realizing for years. It has a weird book that mentions explorers getting mauled, mysterious writings and hints some eldritch abomination that may or may not warp your judgement. And even if imaginationfags are right and Heath made up all of this, then you still have the eldritch abomination that can turn the creepy made up stuff into reality.

There's some "psychological horror" stuff here too. Maybe it's not that dark but it's shaped in a way that makes it feel creepy. Aside from the Plasma stuff I don't see any past plot being better than this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I really dislike when they drastically change the concept with cross gen evos. Its not ALWAYS bad (Basculegion pretty strongly shifts from literally my mom's pirhanna to channeling the lifeforce of the death of a school of fish, and its badass for it), or hyper focus on one element. The results are shoddy.

Rhyperior, for example, leans super fucking heavily into the drill part of Rhydon, turning it into a construction worker for some reason. Rhydon was supposed to be a cool Kaiju with a drill, not explicitly meant to be a jobmon. It drastically shifts the appeal of the Pokemon in question.

Lickilicki's another example of hyper focusing. Lickitung is a salamander tongue monster, and instead of keeping that varied, semi-natural quality, they said "fuck it hes an obese gourmand". It's this really one-track-minded way of designing, uninteresting, and hurts the appeal of the design. It's no longer a weird monster, its a silly joke creature.

Magnezone turns from a multiplying magnetic robot organism, which is a cool, cold, almost mathematical/kaleidoscopic/fractal concept, into a fuckin UFO. I dont hate Magnezone, but its so much more stereotypical than Magneton, and way less cool as a result.

It doesn't help that these designs are just pretty ugly in general too. Rhyperior is at least monstrous and strong, but its also obese and unwieldy. Something like Mismagius shifts tracks pretty fucking hard too (Nukekubi yokai to a generic witch), but it at least looks pleasant.
